header.p: I own some guitars and guitar-like instruments.

text.p: This guitar is so light, but it has a vibrant sound. She's a cutaway acoustic-electric with built-in tuner and 2-band EQ.

I bought this guitar off the side of the road. A woman was selling it; her son had owned and played it but had moved out or whatever and it wasn't being used. I came over, tried it out, and took it home.

Originally this guitar was a Stratocaster copy made by Kramer. The body and headstock were entirely covered in tiger fur. That's right, tiger fur. I don't know whether that's the way it came or whether that was a custom job. The paint underneath was black. At any rate, I stripped off the shag and painted the body a nice pink color. I still have to go back and lacquer this paint job...someday.

I replaced all of the electronics with a standard Stratocaster setup from the 90s, with Lace Sensor Gold pickups and Ernie Ball trim pots (I think). All I need is a new neck and it will be a pretty decent custom Strat copy.
This ukulele is fun to play. Not only does it have a cutaway, but it is also acoustic-electric, with a GREAT amplified sound.

I got this guitar for my birthday many years back. It was the first guitar I could call my own. It has a great sound, but miserable action--the strings are too high and no neck adjustment is possible.

My buddy was throwing this guitar out. I didn't figure out why it was so worthless until I got it home. The strings are a bitch to change because the bridge and pins are so cheap. The entire neck is twisted or warped in such a way that the strings touch the fretboard when they're depressed (which results in buzzing). I decided to open-tune this guitar and keep it around for experimenting with slide technique.
